propositions.text: On January 27, 1995, physicist Marian MacLean observed rotating gray-white smoke above Antarctica.
Initial belief was that these were ordinary sandstorms.
The smoke did not change shape or move over time.
A weather balloon launched to observe the smoke disappeared into it.
Upon retrieval, the balloon's timer showed January 27, 1965, 30 years prior.
Subsequent experiments confirmed time reversal.
This phenomenon was named 'Time Gate' or 'Bug Eye'.
It was speculated that the rotating space over Antarctica was a passage to other eras.
Research became secret after a report to President Clinton.
Ten years later, a secret document reported the survival of the last tribal leader of a 7000-year-old matriarchal clan, Dunshui Holy Mother, in Yunnan, China.
Presidential envoy Michael Stevenson visited Beijing with a team of American experts in multi-dimensional spacetime and biology, led by Marian MacLean.
The chapter 'Bug Eye, Bird Eye, Corpse Eye' discusses book reviews, updates, and related book recommendations on the website http://www.xiaoshuotxt.com/xuanyi/5453/.
TXT Novel Paradise (http://www.xiaoshuotxt.com) is described as a literary website offering classic novels, martial arts fiction, romance, and humanities and social science books for online reading.
It provides free mobile downloads of all TXT e-books.
The selection aims for classics and completeness rather than quantity.
The text includes a stanza from Bai Juyi's 'Song of the Pipa Player' and its historical context.
The poem was written in the autumn of the 11th year of Tang Xianzong's reign (816 AD) when Bai Juyi was demoted to Jiangzhou.
It expresses the poet's melancholy and shared feelings of being out of favor with the Pipa player.
Shortly after Bai Juyi left Jiangzhou, a pavilion named 'Pipa Pavilion' was built at the spot where he saw off guests.
The pavilion was rebuilt in 1746 by the playwright Tang Ying but was destroyed during the Xianfeng era.
Over a hundred years later, only ruins and the inscription 'Ancient Pipa Pavilion' remained.
In the late winter, on a rainy night in Jiujiang, a small tavern named 'Pipa Pavilion Hotel' is described.
The tavern has four tables, with two occupied: one by a middle-aged man and a young girl, the other by four young tourists from the north.
The tourists are discussing Bai Juyi and the Pipa player, with the innkeeper interjecting historical details.
A young tourist recounts a strange incident at Ankang Hospital.
A newborn baby had eyes all over its scalp.
As the tavern closes, a group of tired travelers in a truck enter.
The innkeeper initially refuses service, but the innkeeper's wife offers tea.
The travelers become agitated, and the elder among them approaches the innkeeper's wife menacingly.
The middle-aged man with the girl intervenes with a cryptic remark: 'Dust to dust, earth to earth, where you come from, where you go.'
The travelers leave abruptly.
The middle-aged man reveals that the travelers were 'dead people'.
The next day, a local newspaper reports a湖北 truck accident where five passengers drowned.
Chapter 1: In Jiujiang, formerly known as Chai Sang, Jiangzhou, then Jiujiang, the story moves to Weijia Town, a gateway to Mount Lu and near Poyang Lake.
On a clear morning, Feng Shengcun, a renowned Feng Shui master from Hebei, walks with his young daughter, Jiachen, searching for a cemetery site.
Feng Shengcun identifies a suitable location on a hill with auspicious natural features.
He learns the area is called Hejiashan, with a pond named Talientang, and the nearby village is Dengqiao Village.
The narrative shifts to Zhongdian, Yunnan, at an altitude of over 3000 meters, described as Shangri-La.
In April, the high mountain meadows are covered in purple wildflowers, with Jade Dragon Snow Mountain in the distance.
Deep within the primeval forest lies the clear, pristine Bita Lake.
The lake is guarded by aggressive, large crows and inhabited by the delicious twin-lip fish.
On an island in the lake, a simple stone house is believed to be where the second Karmapa, a leader of the Karma Kagyu sect, meditated.
Inside the house, a thin Living Buddha, Zhongba Rinpoche, wearing monastic robes and a crown, stands before a portrait of Padmasambhava.
Rinpoche speaks to Zewang Renzeng, who has been meditating for thirteen years.
Rinpoche expresses concern about Zewang Renzeng's lack of worldly knowledge and imparts a killing mantra, warning of its heavy karma.
Zewang Renzeng, now twenty, was originally Han Chinese from Tangshan, Hebei.
He was rescued by the Dongba Lama thirteen years prior when he was near death in the mountains.
The Lama adopted him, named him Zewang Renzeng, and taught him the Kagyu lineage.
The principles of Esoteric Buddhism (Tibetan: Sang-ngö) involve secret teachings transmitted only to those with 'capacity'.
Esoteric Buddhism explores the human body's mysteries and potential through 'three secrets': mantras, mudras, and visualization.
Mantras, as discovered by modern science, possess incredible energy through vibration and penetration.
Esoteric practitioners utilize this sonic energy to resonate with 'channels and acupoints' in the body, stimulating internal energy, strengthening the body, and healing.
Advanced practitioners can generate powerful infrasound frequencies.
The rigorous practice of reciting mantras, typically 108 or 1080 times per session, with a goal of 100,000 recitations per mantra.
Zewang Renzeng completed his mantra practice in two months, a feat usually taking over two years for those with good 'capacity'.
He then progressed to 'Five Classes of Supreme Vajra' practices, a high level of yogic attainment.
While Indian classical yoga focuses on external practices, supreme yoga emphasizes internal cultivation, leading to the cessation of consciousness.
Human intelligence operates on four levels: consciousness, unconsciousness, subconsciousness, and deep consciousness.
Esoteric practitioners, through special techniques, directly stimulate the limbic system's deep consciousness, unlocking latent abilities and experiences from before individual existence.
This process leads to an elevation of wisdom, explaining the phenomenon of reincarnation in Tibetan Buddhism.
In his eighth year at the monastery, Zewang Renzeng began practicing 'Fire Yoga' (Tummo).
Tummo involves concentrating on the channels, winds, and bindus to heat the navel chakra, causing 'fire' to rise through the central channel to the crown chakra.
Upon mastering Tummo, practitioners progress to 'Great Illusory Yoga', 'Dream Yoga', and 'Luminous Yoga'.
A year prior, he began the highest practice in Tibetan Esoteric Buddhism: 'Bardo Meditation Yoga'.
'Bardo' signifies an intermediate state between death and rebirth.
For this practice, Zewang Renzeng sealed himself in a dark cave for forty-nine days, meditating without food or water, with contact only possible through his master.
The forty-nine days represent the transition period after death, where the practitioner simulates the Bardo state and its illusions.
During the meditation, he experienced visions of various Buddhas and realms, ultimately merging with a brilliant light.
On the forty-ninth day, Zewang Renzeng emerged from the cave, now a supremely accomplished yogi.
The next day, he left the monastery, with Rinpoche giving him civilian clothes and the name 'Tangshan'.
Chapter 2: During the Qingming Festival, Jiujiang Hejiashan Cemetery is bustling with visitors.
Daoist nun Huaqing, abbess of 'Kaitian Ancient Temple', is recognized for her skills in divination.
Huaqing encounters a young girl, Jiachen, playing with puppies, and is struck by her beauty.
Jiachen leads Huaqing to her father, Feng Shengcun, who is also looking for the nun.
Feng Shengcun confides in Huaqing about his daughter's unusual development, including early and rapid language acquisition and the claim of being taught by a long-bearded old man.
Jiachen's ability to read traditional Chinese characters and correct Feng Shui texts further mystifies him.
Huaqing suspects Jiachen might possess 'heavenly eye' ability.
She explains that young children, with their pure minds, are more susceptible to such abilities, linked to the pineal gland.
When asked, Jiachen identifies the old man as 'Master Laibuyi'.
This revelation shocks Huaqing and Feng Shengcun, as Laibuyi was a famous Song Dynasty Feng Shui master.
Huaqing theorizes that Laibuyi's tomb might be nearby.
Feng Shengcun recalls that during the construction of his house, they hit an ancient tomb.
Jiachen, when questioned about her master's home, states she cannot reveal it as she is the 29th generation successor of the Jiangxi school and has a secret to learn.
She then inadvertently reveals that her master's home is 'downstairs'.
Chapter 3: In the ancient city of Lijiang, Tangshan (Zewang Renzeng) wanders, reflecting on his past.
He recalls his childhood in Qianbao Mountain village, his parents' love, and his father's death in the Tangshan earthquake of 1976.
His mother, heartbroken, returned to her home province to give birth to him, naming him Tangshan.
They eventually returned to Qianbao Mountain, living a difficult life.
While eating noodles, Tangshan witnesses an elderly man collapse, seemingly from a stroke.
Tangshan uses his qi gong to quickly diagnose and treat the man's condition, unblocking his meridians.
The elderly man, revealed to be Hua Xin, the secular brother of Huaqing Daochang, is grateful and offers to help Tangshan, whose backpack and belongings have disappeared.
Hua Xin, a former geologist turned businessman, offers to fund Tangshan's travels.
Later that night, Tangshan is disturbed by the memory of his mother's familiar blue floral top, lost on the day he started school, and the discovery of a bloody garment on the railway tracks.
Two men, led by 'Boss Cui', break into Tangshan and Hua Xin's hotel room, demanding something from Hua Xin.
Hua Xin, desperate, reveals a luminous pearl, a priceless treasure that belonged to Empress Dowager Cixi and Empress Dowager Ci'an.
The pearl's history is recounted: stolen from Ci'an's tomb, passed through various hands, and hidden by Hua Xin's father to protect it.
Tangshan uses a 'Soul Shifting Mantra' to incapacitate Boss Cui and his henchman, making them inject themselves.
Tangshan and Hua Xin escape with the pearl.
Chapter 4: In Qianbao Mountain village, Tangshan's mother sits by the West Big River, a beggar, still searching for her son.
She recalls losing her wedding garment, a cherished item, on the day Tangshan started school.
She learns that Tangshan, after seeing a bloody garment on the railway tracks, went mad and disappeared.
Years pass, and she continues her search, eventually returning to Qianbao Mountain village, where she daily sits by the old white pine, gazing into the distance.
On a northbound train, Tangshan encounters the renowned qi gong master Yan Xin.
Yan Xin demonstrates 'Qi Escape', a powerful qi gong technique.
Yan Xin explains the concept of 'Bug Eyes' (wormholes), natural portals connecting different spaces.
He states that many Bug Eyes are located along the 30th parallel north, citing locations like the Bermuda Triangle, Egyptian Pyramids, and Poyang Lake.
He claims that ancient Feng Shui masters like Yuan Tiangang, Li Chunfeng, Laibuyi, and Liu Bowen were aware of and sought out these Bug Eyes.
Yan Xin explains that Bug Eyes are 'acupoints' of the earth, points where dimensions intersect, characterized by anomalous magnetic vortexes.
The effects of these Bug Eyes are often astounding, including disappearances in the Bermuda Triangle, the Roswell UFO incident, the curse of the pharaohs, and even the Tangshan earthquake.

concepts.name: Marian MacLean
concepts.context: American physicist who observed phenomena in Antarctica and led a research team.

concepts.name: Antarctica
concepts.context: Location of the 'Bug Eye' phenomenon observed by Marian MacLean.

concepts.name: Bug Eye
concepts.context: Phenomenon interpreted as a 'Time Gate' or a passage to other eras, also referred to as 'wormholes' in a later context.

concepts.name: Time Gate
concepts.context: Alternative name for the 'Bug Eye' phenomenon.

concepts.name: Dunshui Holy Mother
concepts.context: Last tribal leader of a 7000-year-old matriarchal clan found in Yunnan, China.

concepts.name: Michael Stevenson
concepts.context: Presidential envoy who visited Beijing with a research team.

concepts.name: Bai Juyi
concepts.context: Tang Dynasty poet, author of 'Song of the Pipa Player', associated with Jiangzhou and the Pipa Pavilion.

concepts.name: Pipa Pavilion
concepts.context: A pavilion built in Jiujiang, named after Bai Juyi's poem, with a history of rebuilding and destruction.

concepts.name: Jiujiang
concepts.context: City where several events take place, including the Pipa Pavilion, the tavern, and the cemetery.

concepts.name: Pipa Pavilion Hotel
concepts.context: A small tavern in Jiujiang where a significant conversation and supernatural event occur.

concepts.name: Ankang Hospital
concepts.context: Hospital where a baby was born with multiple eyes on its scalp.

concepts.name: Mount Lu
concepts.context: A mountain near Jiujiang, associated with Weijia Town.

concepts.name: Poyang Lake
concepts.context: Large freshwater lake in China, mentioned in relation to Jiujiang and as a site of 'Bug Eyes'.

concepts.name: Feng Shui
concepts.context: The art of geomancy, practiced by Feng Shengcun and associated with Laibuyi.

concepts.name: Feng Shengcun
concepts.context: A Feng Shui master, known as 'Feng Buyi', father of Jiachen.

concepts.name: Jiachen
concepts.context: Feng Shengcun's daughter, who exhibits unusual abilities and claims to be taught by Laibuyi.

concepts.name: Shangri-La
concepts.context: A mythical paradise described in literature, identified with Zhongdian, Yunnan.

concepts.name: Bita Lake
concepts.context: A pristine lake in Yunnan, part of a primeval forest, guarded by aggressive crows.

concepts.name: Zhongba Rinpoche
concepts.context: A Living Buddha, spiritual leader who rescued and trained Zewang Renzeng.

concepts.name: Zewang Renzeng
concepts.context: The protagonist, originally Han Chinese named Tangshan, trained as a Tibetan Buddhist lama.

concepts.name: Esoteric Buddhism
concepts.context: Tibetan Buddhism, emphasizing secret teachings, mantras, mudras, and visualization for spiritual development.

concepts.name: Mantras
concepts.context: Sacred utterances used in Esoteric Buddhism for spiritual power and practices.

concepts.name: Qi Gong
concepts.context: Chinese system of exercises and meditation focused on cultivating and balancing life energy (qi).

concepts.name: Tummo
concepts.context: Tibetan Buddhist practice of 'Fire Yoga', involving heating the body's inner energy.

concepts.name: Bardo Meditation Yoga
concepts.context: The highest practice in Tibetan Esoteric Buddhism, involving meditation on the intermediate state between death and rebirth.

concepts.name: Kaitian Ancient Temple
concepts.context: A Daoist temple in Jiujiang, headed by Huaqing Daochang.

concepts.name: Huaqing Daochang
concepts.context: Abbess of Kaitian Ancient Temple, skilled in divination and prophecy.

concepts.name: Laibuyi
concepts.context: Famous Song Dynasty Feng Shui master, revered as the 'ancestor' of Jiachen's lineage and possibly buried near the cemetery.

concepts.name: Heavenly Eye
concepts.context: The ability to perceive spiritual or unseen realms, attributed to Jiachen.

concepts.name: Lijiang Ancient City
concepts.context: The setting where Tangshan, now in civilian clothes, arrives after leaving the monastery.

concepts.name: Tangshan Earthquake
concepts.context: A major earthquake in 1976 that killed Tangshan's father and is later linked to 'Bug Eyes'.

concepts.name: Hua Xin
concepts.context: Secular brother of Huaqing Daochang, a geologist and businessman, who encounters Tangshan and is saved by him.

concepts.name: Luminous Pearl
concepts.context: A priceless treasure belonging to Empress Dowager Cixi and Ci'an, sought by Boss Cui and found by Hua Xin.

concepts.name: Soul Shifting Mantra
concepts.context: A Tibetan Buddhist mantra used by Tangshan to manipulate his opponents.

concepts.name: Boss Cui
concepts.context: A villainous character who pursues Hua Xin for the luminous pearl.

concepts.name: Yan Xin
concepts.context: A famous Chinese Qi Gong master who explains the concept of 'Bug Eyes'.

concepts.name: Qi Escape
concepts.context: A high-level Qi Gong technique described by Yan Xin.

concepts.name: Wormholes
concepts.context: An astronomical term used to explain 'Bug Eyes', connecting different spaces.

concepts.name: 30th Parallel North
concepts.context: A latitude line where many 'Bug Eyes' are believed to be located.

concepts.name: Tang Dynasty
concepts.context: Historical period of Bai Juyi.

concepts.name: Song Dynasty
concepts.context: Historical period of Laibuyi.

concepts.name: Xianfeng era
concepts.context: Period during which the Pipa Pavilion was destroyed.

concepts.name: Qingming Festival
concepts.context: Traditional Chinese festival for honoring ancestors.

concepts.name: Esoteric Buddhism
concepts.context: Also referred to as Tibetan Buddhism.

concepts.name: Yin Yang
concepts.context: Concept of dualism, used in relation to 'Bug Eyes' and 'Yin Yang Gate'.

concepts.name: Yin Yang Gate
concepts.context: Chinese folk term for 'Bug Eyes'.

concepts.name: Bermuda Triangle
concepts.context: A region known for mysterious disappearances, cited as a location with 'Bug Eyes'.

concepts.name: Egyptian Pyramids
concepts.context: Ancient structures cited as locations with 'Bug Eyes'.

concepts.name: Roswell
concepts.context: Town associated with a UFO incident, linked to 'Bug Eyes'.

concepts.name: Pharaohs
concepts.context: Rulers of ancient Egypt, associated with curses and Pyramids.

hierarchy.structure: The document follows a chapter-based structure, beginning with scientific and historical mysteries, then delving into personal narratives interwoven with spiritual and supernatural elements, and concluding with philosophical reflections on fate and the unknown. Each chapter introduces new characters and plotlines that connect to the overarching themes.
